nameEntry.part: Salvation Army Home for Neglected Girls, Perth

biogHist.abstract: The Salvation Army Home for Neglected Girls was established in 1894 in Claisebrook Road, Perth (East Perth), for women and girls with a range of needs. The Home moved to Summers Street, East Perth in 1895. In 1898, new premises were built and the Home moved to Cornelie House in Lincoln Street (North Perth, Highgate).
biogHist.p: The Salvation Army Home for Neglected Girls began on 27 December 1894 at Claisebrook Road, after Cheriton Street, East Perth. It was also known as the Salvation Army Rescue Home.

The Home was established by J and H Fuller, female Salvation Army officers, who came to Western Australia from Melbourne and Adelaide for this purpose. In a memoir recalling the Home, J Fuller reported that the first house, in Claisebrook Road, was a 'nice cottage but the conveniences and water supply were a fair distance from the home' with a deep well from which water could be drawn with difficulty, and had to be strained before it was fit to use. At first, 'girls and women were not eager to come to the Home' and the first resident was admitted on 27 December 1894. An official opening was held on 18 February 1895 and the Home 'was soon full', according to Fuller, who described the Home as 'a Rescue Home, Maternity and preventive Home'.
At the end of 1895, Fuller reported that the Home moved 'almost opposite', to Summers Street, after West Parade, East Perth.
In 1898, the Home moved to Lincoln Street, Highgate (North Perth) and became Cornelie House (or Cornelie Home). The original house in Claisebrook Road was demolished in 2007.

chronItem.event: Address - The Salvation Army Home for Neglected Girls was in leased premises 192 Claisebrook Road, East Perth
Location - The Salvation Army Home for Neglected Girls was located in Summers Street, East Perth

archref.abstract: 'Cornelie Home, Lincoln Street' is a digital copy of an entry in Southern Soup-Soap-Salvation, a compendium of Salvation Army Social Services in the Australian Southern Territory (p.43). It has some historical information about Cornelie.

archref.repository: Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA, Summer St. Rescue Home closed social work file
archref.abstract: 'Summer St Rescue Home 1895' is a digital copy of a photocopied map of East Perth in 1900 that is held in the Summer St. Rescue Home closed social work file at the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA. A handwritten, highlighted note shows the location of the Salvation Army Home for Neglected Girls, or 'Rescue Home', in Summers Street, and identifies the publishing date and source of the map.

archref.repository: Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA, Summer St. Rescue Home closed social work file
archref.abstract: 'Second Salvation Army Rescue Home' is a digital copy of four photographs mounted on two pieces of paper and held in the Summer St. Rescue Home closed social work file at the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA. The typed captions on the item show that the item was prepared in 2009. The images show the first (Claisebrook Road) and second (Summers Street) locations of the Salvation Army Home for Neglected Girls, or 'Rescue Home', in East Perth. A caption also confirms that the Claisebrook Road house was demolished in 2007. Although the caption identifies the Summers Street property as the second rescue home, a memoir written by the officer who established the Home shows that it was the second location of the original Home.

archref.repository: Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA, Image on display
archref.abstract: 'Rescue Home Perth' is a digital copy of an item that is part of the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA, Artefacts series of records. The item is a photocopied excerpt from The War Cry dated 21 March 1992 that is on display in the museum and that is also held in the Summer St. Rescue Home closed social work file, in the Children's Homes series of records. The version held in the file has a typed caption identifies the location of the Home as 192 Claisebrook Road, East Perth and reports that the sketch was made in 2001 by Peter Harper. It shows house used by the Salvation Army Home for Neglected Girls as it looked in 2001.

archref.repository: Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA, Cornelie Court social homes closed file
archref.abstract: 'The First Home, 1894' is a digital copy of an image published in the March 2002 Quarterly Newsletter, Historical Society WA Chapter , which is held in the Cornelie Court social homes closed lever-arch file at the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA. The image shows the Salvation Army Rescue Home (Home for Neglected Girls) at its first location in Claisebrook Road, Perth, in 1894.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Quarterly Newsletter, Historical Society WA Chapter

archref.repository: Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA, Cornelie Court social homes closed file
archref.unittitle: Quarterly Newsletter, Historical Society WA Chapter
archref.abstract: 'Quarterly Newsletter, Historical Society WA Chapter' is a digital copy of an item held in the Cornelie Court social homes closed lever-arch file at the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA. The item is printed excerpts from the 'Jan/Feb/March 2002' newsletter, which features the Cornelie Home, an overview of the 'social work' activities of the Salvation Army in Western Australia in the early years of the twentieth century.
